ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Philosophical argument, how to talk about God, distinguishing between philosophy and theology, arguments and motivations for the omni God/natural theism God

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good and up-to-date readings, good feedback on papers, good assignments. Seminars were a bit challenging just because the professor wasn't happy with many answers; at the same time his small lectures were usually clear and helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to somebody interested in the topics on the syllabus, which are genuinely covered. It's a better course for those interested in philosophy I think than in religious studies or theology, but it also feels like it requires a background in theology. Doing the readings and thinking about them and going to office hours might help you learn more than seminar discussion.
